action_space.name: Therapeutic Alliance Building and Maintenance
action_space.description: Establishing and nurturing a collaborative, trusting relationship with the patient through empathy, care, and respect.

goal.objective: Build a mutually respectful and collaborative relationship that supports therapeutic work.

success_levels.ideal: Patient feels understood, respected, and actively engaged in treatment.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient is generally cooperative and willing to participate, though some hesitancy or mild disengagement may remain.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient feels misunderstood, distant, or resistant, hindering progress.

goal.reward_hint: Patient expresses trust, willingness to collaborate, and positive feedback about their connection to the therapist.

states: When patient expresses concerns or mistrust
Throughout therapy, especially after setbacks or ruptures in engagement
When resistance or negative attitudes toward therapy emerge

micro_actions.name: Demonstrate Empathy and Understanding
micro_actions.description: Reflect back the patient's feelings and experiences, express genuine care verbally and nonverbally; use affirming and validating language.
states: When patient shares distressing or vulnerable experiences
When trust or engagement is questioned
Following setbacks or ruptures in engagement

micro_actions.name: Normalize Patient Experiences
micro_actions.description: Reframe symptoms, emotions, or doubts as common human responses; explain that difficulties are understandable.
states: When patient expresses shame, self-criticism, or doubts about therapy

micro_actions.name: Invite and Validate Feedback
micro_actions.description: Regularly ask for the patient’s views on session progress, comfort level, and alliance; respond supportively to concerns or criticisms.
states: When disengagement or resistance is observed

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Language Use
micro_actions.description: Use language indicating teamwork (e.g., 'Let’s look at this together', 'How does that sound to you?').
states: Any time tasks or ideas are introduced

action_space.name: Individualized Cognitive Conceptualization and Assessment
action_space.description: Collaboratively identifying, mapping, and refining an understanding of the patient's problems, cognitive processes, and developmental factors.

goal.objective: Develop a clear, evolving case formulation that guides intervention selection.

success_levels.ideal: Case conceptualization is accurate, detailed, and shared with the patient, informing effective treatment planning.
success_levels.acceptable: Conceptualization addresses main concerns but misses some nuance or details.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Core issues and cognitive processes are misunderstood, resulting in misaligned interventions.

goal.reward_hint: Therapist articulates and adapts conceptualization as therapy progresses and patient feedback improves model accuracy.

states: When new problems or patterns arise
When current interventions are ineffective and a revised understanding is needed
Before major shifts in technique or strategy

micro_actions.name: Ask Targeted Assessment Questions
micro_actions.description: Pose specific questions about recent mood, functioning, and history (e.g., 'Tell me about a typical day', 'What recent events have affected you?').
states: Whenever new patterns or symptoms arise

micro_actions.name: Probe for Automatic Thoughts and Affect Shifts
micro_actions.description: Ask about thoughts and feelings in key moments ('What went through your mind when that happened?'), explore affective and physiological reactions.
states: During distress or significant mood change

micro_actions.name: Track Patterns Across Situations
micro_actions.description: Summarize and organize patient experiences, noting recurring themes or triggers to inform conceptualization.
states: When assessing the temporal or situational consistency of symptoms or behaviors

micro_actions.name: Check Conceptualization Accuracy
micro_actions.description: Review and verbally share the preliminary case model; directly ask for patient feedback on accuracy or resonance ('Does this fit with your experience?').
states: After developing initial or revised models

micro_actions.name: Gather Data for Hypothesis Refinement
micro_actions.description: Systematically solicit information (e.g., recent events, responses, homework data) to fine-tune the conceptualization.

action_space.name: Socialization to CBT and Psychoeducation
action_space.description: Educating the patient about the CBT model, treatment structure, and rationale to increase understanding and engagement.

goal.objective: Ensure the patient understands how CBT works and feels empowered to participate.

success_levels.ideal: Patient demonstrates accurate understanding of the CBT model and process, and shows enthusiasm to apply concepts.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient understands main principles but occasionally requires clarification.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient is confused or disengaged, resistant to concepts of CBT.

goal.reward_hint: Patient can explain core CBT principles and rationale for interventions in their own words.

states: When patient seems unsure or skeptical about therapy
When introducing new CBT tools or phases

micro_actions.name: Explain CBT Structure and Rationale
micro_actions.description: Clearly describe the phases, agenda setting, mood checks, and homework, using non-jargon and examples.
states: Whenever procedures are new or questioned

micro_actions.name: Use Diagrams or Analogies
micro_actions.description: Provide visual aids or analogies to clarify cognitive concepts, models, or processes (e.g., pie charts, core belief worksheets).
states: When patient struggles to understand verbal descriptions

micro_actions.name: Check and Reinforce Understanding
micro_actions.description: Regularly ask patients to summarize their grasp of CBT concepts ('Can you explain how this model works?'), gently correct misunderstandings.
states: After each new concept is taught

micro_actions.name: Normalize Skill Learning Process
micro_actions.description: Express that making mistakes or gradual learning is expected and beneficial in CBT, reducing patient anxiety or perfectionism.
states: When patient expresses self-doubt or mistakes
Early sessions and whenever patient attempts new skills

action_space.name: Collaborative Agenda Setting and Goal Definition
action_space.description: Jointly determining session focus and broader behavioral goals that are meaningful to the patient.

goal.objective: Establish clear, achievable agendas and goals that guide focused therapeutic work.

success_levels.ideal: Patient actively participates in agenda setting and goal formation and agrees with priorities.
success_levels.acceptable: Agendas and goals are established, though collaboration is somewhat limited.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient feels ignored, misunderstood, and does not engage in goal or agenda setting.

goal.reward_hint: Patient contributes suggestions and agrees with agenda and goals each session.

states: When shifting focus due to changing needs
When evaluating progress or clarifying direction

micro_actions.name: Solicit Agenda Items from Patient
micro_actions.description: Directly ask the patient what topics or concerns they wish to address ('What would you like to focus on today?').
states: Whenever focus is unclear or shifting

micro_actions.name: Outline and Confirm Agenda Collaboratively
micro_actions.description: Summarize proposed topics, check for agreement ('Does this agenda work for you?'), revise as needed until consensus.
states: At start and during agenda setting

micro_actions.name: Prioritize Urgent or Pressing Items
micro_actions.description: Assess and negotiate priorities based on current distress, new events, or pressing patient needs.

micro_actions.name: Refine Behavioral Goals Collaboratively
micro_actions.description: Prompt patient to specify goals in actionable terms; reframe vague or external goals to self-agency and specific behaviors.
states: Whenever initial goals are unclear or broad

action_space.name: Cognitive and Behavioral Intervention Training
action_space.description: Teaching and practicing core CBT skills, including identifying and responding to dysfunctional thoughts, beliefs, and behaviors.

goal.objective: Enable the patient to effectively apply cognitive and behavioral strategies to reduce distress and modify patterns.

success_levels.ideal: Patient demonstrates independent use of skills and reports improvement in target symptoms.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient understands and practices skills during therapy and homework, but needs continued guidance.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient is unable or unwilling to apply strategies or misunderstands techniques.

goal.reward_hint: Patient successfully uses CBT techniques both in-session and as homework; reports mastery or progress.

states: When teaching new techniques or responding to observed dysfunctional patterns
When reviewing homework or practicing new skills

micro_actions.name: Teach Identification of Automatic Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Ask the patient to recall and articulate automatic thoughts during distressing moments, using probing questions ('What went through your mind right then?').
states: Whenever patient has difficulty identifying thoughts

micro_actions.name: Use Socratic Questioning for Guided Discovery
micro_actions.description: Pose collaborative, open-ended questions to examine and evaluate thoughts and beliefs (e.g., 'What's the evidence?', 'Is there an alternative explanation?').
states: During behavioral experiments or thought evaluation

micro_actions.name: Model and Practice Skill Use
micro_actions.description: Demonstrate use of CBT skills, coach patient through step-by-step completion (e.g., thought records, coping cards), encourage rehearsal in session.
states: When patient struggles or lacks confidence

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Assignment of Behavioral Experiments
micro_actions.description: Guide the patient in designing and planning experiments to test or apply cognitive or behavioral skills.
states: When evaluating the utility of new skills

micro_actions.name: Provide Corrective Feedback on Technique Use
micro_actions.description: Gently correct misapplications of skills, offering encouragement and clarification for improvement.
states: During skill practice or homework review

action_space.name: Identifying, Evaluating, and Restructuring Dysfunctional Cognitions
action_space.description: Jointly uncovering, questioning, and modifying automatic thoughts, intermediate beliefs, and core beliefs with cognitive and experiential techniques.

goal.objective: Help the patient recognize and shift maladaptive thinking patterns to more adaptive ones.

success_levels.ideal: Patient reliably identifies and challenges dysfunctional thoughts and beliefs; beliefs and emotional responses are more adaptive.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient can sometimes identify and shift thoughts with support and guidance.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient is unable to recognize or modify dysfunctional cognitions.

goal.reward_hint: Patient demonstrates change in thinking patterns via worksheets, reporting, or behavioral experiments.

states: When cognitive distortions are linked to patient distress
During targeted evaluation of specific problematic beliefs
When major emotional or behavioral shifts are needed

micro_actions.name: Elicit and Label Automatic Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Directly prompt the patient to articulate automatic thoughts and label as prediction, interpretation, or core belief; clarify with examples.

micro_actions.name: Evaluate Evidence and Cognitive Distortions
micro_actions.description: Ask Socratic questions about evidence for/against the thought, highlight cognitive distortions, and offer lists for review.

micro_actions.name: Facilitate Distancing Techniques
micro_actions.description: Prompt patient to consider alternative perspectives (e.g., 'What would you tell a friend?' ‘How might someone else view this?’).
states: When patient is stuck in a rigid, self-critical view

micro_actions.name: Guide Formation of Adaptive Responses
micro_actions.description: Assist patient in constructing new, adaptive counter-thoughts or responses through structured questions and collaborative writing.
states: When patients show openness to reframing

micro_actions.name: Assign Practice of New Cognitive Responses
micro_actions.description: Encourage patient to rehearse or record (in Thought Record, coping card, homework) new cognitive responses to be used in real-life situations.
states: At session end, during homework assignment

action_space.name: Emotion Recognition and Processing
action_space.description: Facilitating patient awareness of emotions, differentiating feelings from thoughts, and using emotion data to guide intervention.

goal.objective: Increase patient ability to identify, label, and process emotions as part of cognitive restructuring.

success_levels.ideal: Patient accurately recognizes emotions, rates their intensity, and uses this awareness to inform cognition and behavior change.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient labels emotions with some prompting and considers emotional data in session.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Emotional experiences are overlooked, misunderstood, or avoided; cognitive work is blocked.

goal.reward_hint: Patient can distinguish emotion from thought and reports emotional shifts during intervention.

states: When patient appears emotionally overwhelmed or disengaged

micro_actions.name: Elicit and Label Emotions Explicitly
micro_actions.description: Ask the patient to name and describe specific emotions relating to thoughts or situations ('How were you feeling emotionally?').
states: When discussing distressing or significant events

micro_actions.name: Distinguish Thoughts from Emotions
micro_actions.description: Correct mislabeling, teach the difference explicitly when thoughts and emotions are confused.
states: When patient blends thoughts and feelings

micro_actions.name: Prompt Emotion Intensity Ratings
micro_actions.description: Request patient to rate emotion intensity on numerical or descriptive scales, refer to emotion charts as needed.
states: At start/end of session and after interventions

micro_actions.name: Reinforce Emotional Awareness and Processing
micro_actions.description: Support and validate emotional articulation, encourage exploration of affective shifts and their relationship to cognitions.
states: When emotions are prominent or drive cognition

action_space.name: Structured Session Management
action_space.description: Organizing therapy sessions using a consistent format (introduction, agenda, middle work, summary, and feedback) to maximize efficiency and focus.

goal.objective: Provide a clear and predictable session structure that facilitates progress and collaboration.

success_levels.ideal: Sessions consistently follow the structure, and patient feels oriented, safe, and productive.
success_levels.acceptable: Session structure is mostly maintained; minor deviations occur but do not impede progress.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Sessions are chaotic or unfocused, leading to patient confusion or disengagement.

goal.reward_hint: Session follows planned phases; patient can recall and anticipate structure and engages actively.

states: When sessions lack focus or patient seems disoriented
When introducing new techniques or content

micro_actions.name: Greet and Orient Patient at Session Start
micro_actions.description: Welcome patient, clarify session structure and purpose at the outset.

micro_actions.name: Conduct Mood Check and Quick Review
micro_actions.description: Ask for current mood/narrative, use scales or forms if available.

micro_actions.name: Summarize and Transition Between Phases
micro_actions.description: Verbally mark phase transitions (e.g., after agenda setting, before summary/feedback), keep session on track.

micro_actions.name: Gently Interrupt and Redirect for Focus
micro_actions.description: Employ respectful, brief interruptions to maintain session structure and address digressions.

micro_actions.name: Solicit and Record Session Feedback
micro_actions.description: Ask for feedback on session quality and understanding; encourage written or verbal responses at summary.
states: When negative affect or disengagement is suspected

action_space.name: Homework Assignment, Review, and Troubleshooting
action_space.description: Collaboratively planning, assigning, monitoring, and troubleshooting homework to promote skill acquisition and change between sessions.

goal.objective: Ensure patient consistently practices skills outside sessions and learns from homework experiences.

success_levels.ideal: Patient completes and reflects on homework reliably, applying insights to therapy and daily life.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient attempts homework and learns from partial completion or obstacles.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Homework is misunderstood, neglected, or undermines skill acquisition.

goal.reward_hint: Patient completes homework, learns from reflections, and gains from troubleshooting when difficulties arise.

states: When patient struggles to complete homework or reports obstacles

micro_actions.name: Assign and Discuss Specific Homework Tasks
micro_actions.description: Collaboratively select and clarify individually tailored assignments, review timing, reminders, and address barriers.

micro_actions.name: Review Past Homework Systematically
micro_actions.description: Ask pointed follow-ups about completion, understanding, and reactions to homework; troubleshoot difficulties.
states: When homework is incomplete or challenging

micro_actions.name: Encourage Immediate Recording and Reflection
micro_actions.description: Prompt patient to write down reactions and mastery/pleasure ratings immediately after activities.
states: During activity or symptom monitoring assignments
When using Thought Records or activity charts

micro_actions.name: Adapt Homework Based on Patient Feedback
micro_actions.description: Modify assignments flexibly in response to overwhelm, reluctance, or logistical obstacles.
states: When patient expresses difficulty, boredom, or resistance

micro_actions.name: Reinforce Homework Rationale and Motivation
micro_actions.description: Remind patient of the rationale for each assignment and encourage the use of coping cards, checklists, or supportive reminders.

action_space.name: Relapse Prevention and Termination Planning
action_space.description: Preparing the patient for successful therapy termination and possible setbacks by reviewing skills, supporting autonomy, and planning for maintenance.

goal.objective: Support patient's ability to independently apply CBT concepts post-therapy and respond to future challenges.

success_levels.ideal: Patient confidently transitions to self-therapy, implements relapse prevention plans, and uses booster sessions as needed.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient understands basics of relapse prevention and maintains most gains after therapy ends.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient feels anxious, unprepared, or regresses following therapy termination.

goal.reward_hint: Patient articulates and enacts a personal relapse prevention plan and demonstrates independence from therapist.

states: In later sessions, preparing for end of therapy
In booster or follow-up sessions post-termination

micro_actions.name: Elicit and Address Anticipated Setbacks
micro_actions.description: Ask the patient to envision specific future challenges, setbacks, or lapses, and rehearse coping responses.

micro_actions.name: Review and Summarize Skills Learned
micro_actions.description: Guide the patient to review and record key CBT skills, coping cards, credit lists, and synopses developed in therapy.

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Develop Personalized Relapse Plan
micro_actions.description: Support the patient in outlining specific tools, strategies, and reminders for long-term CBT skill use and problem-solving.
states: When patient expresses concerns about independence

micro_actions.name: Coach Use of Social Support and Booster Sessions
micro_actions.description: Prompt patient to plan for accessing external supports or booster sessions if difficulties arise after termination.
states: When developing a relapse prevention plan

action_space.name: Problem Solving and Skills Training
action_space.description: Teaching and practicing practical skills (e.g., decision-making, assertiveness, social/functional skills, relaxation) to address specific life problems.

goal.objective: Patient acquires targeted skills to handle life challenges and foster adaptive functioning.

success_levels.ideal: Patient masters new skills, uses them independently, and reports improved functioning.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient applies skills with some support or reminders, and sees modest improvement.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Skill acquisition is incomplete and problems persist unaddressed.

goal.reward_hint: Patient can demonstrate skills in-session and report use and benefit in daily life.

states: When specific deficits or skill gaps are identified
To address problems that hinder goal progress
As ongoing support for behavioral change

micro_actions.name: Instruct and Model Skill Steps
micro_actions.description: Directly teach the steps of problem solving, assertiveness, relaxation, or other targeted skills using verbal instruction or demonstration.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Brainstorming of Solutions
micro_actions.description: Encourage patient to list concerns, discuss options, and co-create solutions to specific problems; record proposed solutions.

micro_actions.name: Practice Skills via Role Play and Rehearsal
micro_actions.description: Lead patient through in-session practice, rehearsal, or role-plays for communication, exposure, or behavioral activation tasks.

micro_actions.name: Use Visual Aids and Structured Assignments
micro_actions.description: Guide activity breakdown using pie charts, checklists, or written analyses (e.g., advantages/disadvantages, step lists).

micro_actions.name: Assign Behavioral Exposure and Monitor
micro_actions.description: Together, design and schedule graded exposure tasks, monitor distress and outcome predictions.
states: When avoidance or anxiety is an issue

action_space.name: Session Structure Adjustment and Troubleshooting
action_space.description: Diagnosing and remediating problems with session flow or patient compliance, maintaining engagement and focus.

goal.objective: Restore effective session flow and address obstacles to engagement or progress.

success_levels.ideal: Session is rapidly refocused, and patient re-engages in collaborative work.
success_levels.acceptable: Session regains some focus after adjustments with mild residual disruption.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Session remains unfocused or patient is disengaged despite attempts to troubleshoot.

goal.reward_hint: Therapist identifies source of disruption and session returns to productive, structured flow with patient involvement.

states: When obstacles impede progress or mastery

micro_actions.name: Gently Interrupt and Redirect Patient
micro_actions.description: Politely interrupt digressions, explain rationale for focus, and collaboratively regain session structure.

micro_actions.name: Probe for Nonverbal or Indirect Signs of Disengagement
micro_actions.description: Pay attention to patient cues (tone, body language); verbally check if patient is confused, frustrated, or disengaged.

micro_actions.name: Offer Collaborative Adjustments to Session Structure
micro_actions.description: Propose flexible structure changes (e.g., unstructured time, short break), negotiate new agenda if needed.

action_space.name: Imagery-Based Intervention
action_space.description: Employing imagery techniques to identify, address, and modify imaginal automatic thoughts and emotional experiences.

goal.objective: Patient learns to use imagery adaptively to reduce distress and rehearse coping behaviors.

success_levels.ideal: Patient accurately identifies useful and distressing images, applies interventions, and reports emotional relief and behavioral change.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient tries imagery techniques with occasional success and needs guidance.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Imagery interventions are misunderstood or exacerbate distress.

goal.reward_hint: Patient initiates imagery work and notes positive changes after intervention.

states: When automatic thoughts are accompanied by vivid imagery
When emotions are resistant to verbal cognitive restructuring
When rehearsing coping or preparing for challenging situations

micro_actions.name: Elicit and Clarify Imagery Experiences
micro_actions.description: Persistently ask about mental images and sensations ('What did you see in your mind’s eye?'), probe with synonyms and description requests.
states: When verbal thought evaluation is ineffective

micro_actions.name: Guide Rehearsal and Modification of Images
micro_actions.description: Coach patient in visualizing alternative or adapted images for emotional processing and coping rehearsal.
states: Imagery work for anxiety, sadness, or problem-solving

micro_actions.name: Lead Imagined Scenario Reality Testing
micro_actions.description: Use Socratic questioning on images and imagined scenarios to test predictions and reduce catastrophizing.
states: When distressing images fuel dysfunctional belief

micro_actions.name: Suggest Imagery Substitution or Pleasant Imagery
micro_actions.description: Prompt patient to substitute distressing images with pleasant or neutral ones to modulate affect.
states: When patient is emotionally overwhelmed by imagery

micro_actions.name: Provide Psychoeducation on Imagery Techniques
micro_actions.description: Explain the rationale and stepwise use of imagery techniques, offer in-session practice.

action_space.name: Treatment Planning and Adaptation
action_space.description: Developing and adjusting phased and individualized treatment plans based on diagnosis, symptoms, patient preferences, and progress.

goal.objective: Ensure therapy remains tailored, goal-directed, and relevant to patient's evolving needs.

success_levels.ideal: Plan is collaborative, flexible, and addresses patient’s unique circumstances; patient is motivated and sessions progress smoothly.
success_levels.acceptable: Treatment plan is partially adapted; some phases are tailored but some rigidities remain.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Treatment plan is static, misaligned, or ignored, causing disengagement or stalled progress.

goal.reward_hint: Treatment plan is updated based on feedback, patient progress, and changing clinical presentation.

states: Initial sessions after assessment and conceptualization
When patient’s symptoms, needs, or context change
When interventions are not yielding desired outcomes

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Discuss Treatment Goals and Structure
micro_actions.description: Review treatment plans and options with patient, seek input and agreement on goals, explain rationale for phases.
states: Whenever goals shift or plans are adapted

micro_actions.name: Check Patient Reactions and Acceptance
micro_actions.description: Ask for feedback about proposed plans, elicit concerns, and collaboratively problem-solve misalignments.
states: After presenting new or revised plans

micro_actions.name: Record and Fine-Tune Treatment Plan Iteratively
micro_actions.description: Document revised plans, goals, and schedule; revisit and update regularly based on progress and feedback.
states: When symptoms, needs, or context changes

micro_actions.name: Adjust Interventions Based on Data and Feedback
micro_actions.description: Explicitly solicit and incorporate patient reports, homework outcomes, and distress levels into treatment adaptations.

conversation_states.Description: Current emotional state, including type (e.g., anxiety, sadness) and intensity, and changes over time during session. Guides intervention choices and signals distress levels.
Degree of acute emotional discomfort/distress (e.g., sadness, anxiety, hopelessness) experienced in session. Influences focus and urgency of interventions.
The specific negative or positive automatic thoughts occurring and their associated beliefs/distortions that drive emotions/behaviors.
Strength of the patient’s belief in automatic thoughts or underlying/core beliefs (intellectual/gut feeling). Informs intervention choice and progress.
Patient’s perception of trust, safety, collaboration, and empathy in the therapeutic relationship. It impacts willingness, engagement, and outcomes.
Level of active involvement and collaborative behavior in the session and therapy tasks (agenda, discussion, feedback, activities).
Degree of motivation, hopefulness, and belief in possibility of change, which influences effort and resilience during therapy.
Patient’s progress, success, or difficulty with planned assignments or tasks between sessions. Guides planning and troubleshooting.
Degree of advancement toward in-session or overall therapy goals, used to track effectiveness of interventions.
Patient’s degree of comprehension and buy-in regarding the cognitive model, rationale for interventions, and fit with their issues.
Observed or reported patterns such as avoidance, activation, social engagement, mastery, and achievement across daily life and session tasks.
Presence and type of cognitive processing biases, such as catastrophizing, overgeneralization, dichotomous thinking, or discounting positives.
Willingness of the patient to participate in cognitive evaluation, challenge beliefs, and try new strategies.
Level of overt or covert resistance, skeptical attitude, emotional/cognitive stuckness that impedes progress or signals need for a strategic shift.
Ratings and observed levels of mastery and pleasure after completion of behavioral experiments or scheduled activities.
Presence and quality of involvement (family, friends, caregivers) that influences coping and goal attainment.
Degree to which the patient is cognitively and emotionally ready to move between session segments/phases or tackle proposed agenda items.
Ability and motivation to use CBT tools and techniques independently (e.g., evaluating thoughts, completing worksheets).
Shifts in symptoms (emotional/physiological) and patient’s perceived cause (CBT, life events, medication, etc.).
Perceived difficulty, willingness, and optimism regarding planned activities outside session.
Degree to which deeply held core beliefs (positive or negative) are present and influencing patient’s mood and behavior in session.
Frequency and effectiveness of adaptive or maladaptive coping strategies during session and in reported situations.
Patient’s direct and indirect feedback on session content, therapist effectiveness, and perceived progress.
Progress in covering agreed agenda items and priorities during session, aids time management and focus.
Presence, type, intensity, and persistence of emotional images (as automatic thoughts), patient’s ability to report, visualize, and engage with them.
Acute signs of risk (e.g., suicidality, self-harm) or other pressing life issues requiring urgent attention or adaptation in session.
Frequency and intensity of self-critical thoughts or unfavorable self-comparisons, which can perpetuate distress and resistance.
Psychological, practical, cognitive, or relational barriers inhibiting progress on tasks, homework, or skill acquisition.

nodes.description: Root node representing the individual receiving CBT.
Enduring, central beliefs about self, others, world (e.g., incompetence, unlovability).
Recurring, situation-specific thoughts often linked to distress.
Rules, attitudes, or assumptions that reside between core beliefs and automatic thoughts.
Typical patterns of biased thinking (e.g., catastrophizing, all-or-nothing, mind reading).
Coping, compensatory, adaptive, or maladaptive strategies employed in response to beliefs/thoughts.
Skill repertoire, including mastery/improvement of CBT and emotion regulation tools.
Life events and formative experiences relevant to belief and coping pattern origins.
Precipitating, maintaining, or protective factors/events affecting current problems.
Emotional, cognitive, behavioral, and physiological symptom tracking across time.
Clinical diagnostic status, comorbidities, and longitudinal updates (including DSM/ICD axes).
Quality, evolution, and notable shifts in patient-therapist relationship.
Session-by-session goals, agenda focus, learning, and summary of outcomes.
Record of assignments, completion, obstacles, forms, and learning from tasks/exercises.
Patient’s feedback on therapy, therapy preferences, motivational level, and barriers to engagement.
Previous interventions, therapies, responses, and efficacy patterns.
Progress in skill usage, belief in ability to change or improve mood/function.
History and progress in scheduling/enjoying activities, mastery/pleasure ratings.
Themes, emotional responses, and coping within imagery-based work and exposure.
History and current status of social supports, family involvement, and changes in network.
Patterns of therapy obstacles, setbacks, resistance, and adaptive responses over time.
Change motivation degree, therapy engagement, and response to motivational interventions.
Assets, achievements, areas of resilience/mastery, coping and supports.
Preferences regarding agenda, session flow, structuring difficulties or successes.

cautions.negative_action: Skipping foundational conceptualization and relationship building
cautions.description: Omitting critical initial steps of conceptualizing the case and building rapport to focus on techniques.
cautions.risk: Weak therapeutic alliance, poor case formulation, and less effective interventions.

cautions.negative_action: Persuading, debating, or lecturing when challenging thoughts
cautions.description: Using persuasion or argument instead of collaborative Socratic questioning.
cautions.risk: Patient defensiveness, damaged alliance, and reduced engagement.

cautions.negative_action: Uncritically encouraging overly positive viewpoints
cautions.description: Promoting excessively optimistic perspectives without critical evaluation.
cautions.risk: Invalidation of patient experience and undermining credibility.

cautions.negative_action: Making unilateral changes without patient collaboration or rationale
cautions.description: Introducing new approaches or changes without involving the patient or providing explanation.

cautions.negative_action: Ignoring feedback or patient disengagement
cautions.description: Failing to solicit and address patient reactions or signs of reduced engagement.

cautions.negative_action: Overemphasizing the past unless clinically indicated
cautions.description: Focusing excessively on historical issues unrelated to current problems.
cautions.risk: Reduced present-centered problem solving and lost session focus.

cautions.negative_action: Setting unrealistic or poorly defined goals
cautions.description: Establishing goals that are too ambitious or unclear.
cautions.risk: Undermined patient or therapist confidence due to failure or unfair comparisons.

cautions.negative_action: Applying techniques in a formulaic manner
cautions.description: Using standardized methods without individualizing to patient needs.
cautions.risk: Reduced intervention effectiveness and patient alienation.

cautions.negative_action: Delivering treatment in a rote, cold, or impersonal manner
cautions.description: Providing therapy without warmth, personalization, or empathy.
cautions.risk: Poor engagement, reduced alliance, and limited progress.

cautions.negative_action: Neglecting the therapeutic alliance
cautions.description: Ignoring relationship-building, especially with challenging patients.

cautions.negative_action: Failing to elicit or address negative feedback
cautions.description: Not soliciting or addressing patients’ negative reactions.
cautions.risk: Reduced engagement and poorer treatment outcomes.

cautions.negative_action: Ignoring patient discomfort with therapist style
cautions.description: Failing to adapt therapeutic style based on patient needs.

cautions.negative_action: Excessive time on relationship-building with good alliance
cautions.description: Spending unnecessary time on relationship when alliance is already sound.
cautions.risk: Inefficient use of session time and missed intervention opportunities.

cautions.negative_action: Overlooking planning and individualized homework
cautions.description: Failing to carefully plan and tailor homework assignments.
cautions.risk: Homework nonadherence and limited skill acquisition.

cautions.negative_action: Skipping homework review in subsequent sessions
cautions.description: Not reviewing completed homework or activities.
cautions.risk: Reduced accountability and reinforcement of skills.

cautions.negative_action: Prematurely challenging or modifying entrenched core beliefs
cautions.description: Attempting to change core beliefs before establishing trust and readiness.
cautions.risk: Loss of credibility, alliance rupture, and patient resistance.

cautions.negative_action: Making interpretations not based on actual patient data
cautions.description: Jumping to conclusions or offering unsupported inferences.

cautions.negative_action: Ignoring positive data or invalidating patient lived experience
cautions.description: Overlooking patient-reported strengths or experiences.
cautions.risk: Breakdown of trust and decreased motivation.

cautions.negative_action: Rigidly imposing conceptualizations
cautions.description: Not allowing conceptualizations to be collaborative and iterative.
cautions.risk: Patient resistance and poor therapeutic fit.

cautions.negative_action: Premature application or disclosure of diagnostic labels
cautions.description: Labeling/diagnosing before thorough assessment or patient consent.
cautions.risk: Patient distress or stigma, undermining alliance.

cautions.negative_action: Skipping collection of background information
cautions.description: Omitting gathering of critical medical or psychological history.
cautions.risk: Inaccurate case conceptualization and inappropriate treatment.

cautions.negative_action: Pushing for disclosure without consent
cautions.description: Encouraging patients to share private information without their agreement.
cautions.risk: Violation of boundaries and increased distress.

cautions.negative_action: Overriding preferences about family involvement
cautions.description: Involving family without patient's agreement.

cautions.negative_action: Rigidly adhering to a pre-set agenda
cautions.description: Sticking to the session plan without accommodating patient priorities.

cautions.negative_action: Making overly optimistic promises about treatment outcome
cautions.description: Guaranteeing results without evidence or realistic basis.
cautions.risk: Patient disappointment and loss of trust.

cautions.negative_action: Presenting agenda in a controlling or non-collaborative manner
cautions.description: Directing session structure without patient input.

cautions.negative_action: Forcing adherence to therapist-determined agenda
cautions.description: Insisting on following the therapist's plan at the expense of patient needs.

cautions.negative_action: Overwhelming patient with excessive or difficult homework
cautions.description: Assigning tasks that are too numerous or complex.

cautions.negative_action: Using jargon, stigmatizing language, or unnecessary labels
cautions.description: Employing complex or pejorative language and unneeded diagnoses.

cautions.negative_action: Pushing patient too hard to understand cognitive model or set goals
cautions.description: Forcing comprehension or goal-setting prematurely.
cautions.risk: Feelings of incompetence and reduced engagement.

cautions.negative_action: Attributing all problems solely to patient's thinking
cautions.description: Ignoring real-life factors contributing to difficulties.
cautions.risk: Patient invalidation and incomplete problem solving.

cautions.negative_action: Overwhelming inactive or severely depressed patients
cautions.description: Scheduling too many/difficult activities for patients with low energy or depression.

cautions.negative_action: Ignoring automatic thoughts that undermine activity initiation
cautions.description: Failing to address thoughts that prevent engagement in activities.

cautions.negative_action: Dismissing the effort required for depressed patients
cautions.description: Minimizing how hard it is for depressed patients to engage even in small actions.

cautions.negative_action: Forcing activities without first exploring reluctance
cautions.description: Requiring participation without understanding patient resistance.

cautions.negative_action: Rigidly insisting on activity charts for resistant patients
cautions.description: Mandating use of activity tracking despite patient opposition.

cautions.negative_action: Neglecting rest, leisure, and balance in activities
cautions.description: Focusing only on mastery or pleasure-based activities.

cautions.negative_action: Failing to reinforce credit for completed actions
cautions.description: Not helping patients acknowledge even minor accomplishments.

cautions.negative_action: Allowing excessive elaboration or off-topic content
cautions.description: Letting sessions drift without refocusing on goals.
cautions.risk: Loss of session efficiency and reduced progress.

cautions.negative_action: Blunting emotional impact by paraphrasing automatic thoughts incorrectly
cautions.description: Rephrasing patient thoughts in ways that miss core emotional significance.

cautions.negative_action: Ignoring alliance ruptures or negative feedback
cautions.description: Not following up when relationship issues arise.

cautions.negative_action: Recommending medication changes without qualification
cautions.description: Advising on meds without appropriate credentials or responsibility.

cautions.negative_action: Discussing sensitive agenda items without patient agreement
cautions.description: Introducing difficult subjects without consent.

cautions.negative_action: Skipping homework review or failing to reinforce skill acquisition
cautions.description: Not supporting continued learning or skill development.

cautions.negative_action: Imposing structure in an overbearing or controlling fashion
cautions.description: Managing sessions too rigidly without flexibility.

cautions.negative_action: Failing to attend to affect shifts or resistance
cautions.description: Not responding to changing emotions or resistance during session.
cautions.risk: Missed therapeutic opportunities and worsened distress.

cautions.negative_action: Pushing session elements rigidly when alliance is fragile
cautions.description: Insisting on planned interventions despite poor relationship.

cautions.negative_action: Invalidating patient emotions and beliefs
cautions.description: Challenging or dismissing feelings or beliefs without appropriate pacing.

cautions.negative_action: Failing to summarize and review homework or agenda regularly
cautions.description: Neglecting session structure and accountability.

cautions.negative_action: Providing unclear rationales for forms or assignments
cautions.description: Not explaining the purpose of tasks.

cautions.negative_action: Assuming patient compliance without collaboration
cautions.description: Expecting patients to follow instructions without discussion.

cautions.negative_action: Interrogating or persisting overly aggressively in thought identification
cautions.description: Pushing too hard for answers when patients struggle.

cautions.negative_action: Accepting speculation or vague responses as automatic thoughts
cautions.description: Allowing interpretations or speculative answers to replace actual thoughts.
cautions.risk: Inaccurate case conceptualization and ineffective interventions.

cautions.negative_action: Providing speculative thoughts too often
cautions.description: Suggesting possible thoughts rather than eliciting actual patient cognitions.
cautions.risk: Reinforces interpretations and undermines patient self-discovery.

cautions.negative_action: Neglecting patient understanding of cognitive model and rationale
cautions.description: Failing to check that patients grasp therapy principles.

cautions.negative_action: Focusing exclusively on external events, ignoring internal processes
cautions.description: Not attending to physiological cues or internal stimuli as sources of thoughts.

cautions.negative_action: Overlooking secondary automatic thoughts or affective reactions
cautions.description: Neglecting thoughts and emotions that arise secondarily to initial reactions.
cautions.risk: Missed treatment targets and reduced effectiveness.

cautions.negative_action: Challenging or invalidating patient's emotional experience
cautions.description: Disputing or minimizing emotion without careful pacing.

cautions.negative_action: Ignoring discrepancies between thoughts and emotions
cautions.description: Failing to address mismatched cognitions and feelings.
cautions.risk: Reduced intervention impact and missed insights.

cautions.negative_action: Proceeding with intervention before reducing emotional distress
cautions.description: Advancing therapeutic steps before patient is emotionally ready.

cautions.negative_action: Rigid emotion labeling when patient struggles to name emotions
cautions.description: Insisting on precise emotion naming despite patient difficulty.

cautions.negative_action: Directly or aggressively challenging automatic thoughts
cautions.description: Strongly disputing patient thoughts without collaboration.

cautions.negative_action: Ignoring evidence supporting patient's automatic thought
cautions.description: Discounting information that reinforces the patient’s view.
cautions.risk: Patient feels misunderstood and resists therapy.

cautions.negative_action: Pushing patient to evaluate highly distressing thoughts prematurely
cautions.description: Forcing cognitive restructuring before emotional safety is established.

cautions.negative_action: Imposing cognitive restructuring as therapist correction
cautions.description: Presenting cognitive change as correction rather than collaboration.

cautions.negative_action: Overwhelming patient with too many questions or lists
cautions.description: Bombarding the patient with excessive inquiry at once.

cautions.negative_action: Setting up patient for failure/self-criticism during homework
cautions.description: Assigning tasks that lead to negative self-appraisal.

cautions.negative_action: Overemphasizing worksheets with patients who find them unhelpful
cautions.description: Insisting on worksheet use despite patient overwhelm.

cautions.negative_action: Allowing patient self-criticism about therapy tools or process
cautions.description: Not intervening when patients blame themselves for difficulty with tasks.

cautions.negative_action: Expecting complete relief from negative emotions post-intervention
cautions.description: Pressuring patients to achieve full emotional improvement immediately.

cautions.negative_action: Neglecting to tailor interventions to patient's literacy, motivation, or intellect
cautions.description: Not adjusting methods for individual understanding or capacity.

cautions.negative_action: Presenting conceptualizations as absolute truth
cautions.description: Communicating interpretations as incontrovertible fact.
cautions.risk: Patient resistance and loss of collaboration.

cautions.negative_action: Showing complex conceptual diagrams that may confuse or demean
cautions.description: Using advanced or confusing models with patients likely to misunderstand.

cautions.negative_action: Imposing new beliefs rather than guiding collaboratively
cautions.description: Forcing belief change without joint exploration.

cautions.negative_action: Engaging in persistent probing without rationale or monitoring for distress
cautions.description: Questioning intensively without reason or sensitivity to patient comfort.

cautions.negative_action: Using excessively argumentative or critical techniques
cautions.description: Acting confrontational, especially in role play or exploration.

cautions.negative_action: Over-focusing on peripheral or weakly endorsed beliefs
cautions.description: Prioritizing beliefs that do not meaningfully impact functioning.

cautions.negative_action: Attempting early evaluation of core beliefs before readiness
cautions.description: Assessing rigid or global beliefs before trust is developed.
cautions.risk: Patient invalidation, emotional flooding, and withdrawal.

cautions.negative_action: Invalidating/challenging beliefs too directly or soon
cautions.description: Confronting patient beliefs before therapeutic pacing allows.

cautions.negative_action: Labeling core beliefs as truths rather than hypotheses
cautions.description: Presenting beliefs as factual rather than tentative ideas.
cautions.risk: Rigid belief maintenance and reduced change readiness.

cautions.negative_action: Pressuring patient to adopt unrealistically positive core beliefs
cautions.description: Encouraging belief changes that feel unattainable to the patient.

cautions.negative_action: Pushing for belief exploration when intense affect emerges
cautions.description: Continuing to explore beliefs when patient is overwhelmed.

cautions.negative_action: Providing solutions too quickly without patient input
cautions.description: Offering answers before collaborative exploration.
cautions.risk: Missed insight and reduced patient autonomy.

cautions.negative_action: Reinforcing avoidance or excessive distraction
cautions.description: Encouraging escape from distress rather than skill development.
cautions.risk: Limited skill acquisition and maintenance of symptoms.

cautions.negative_action: Neglecting skill assessment before offering training
cautions.description: Teaching skills before ensuring patient readiness.

cautions.negative_action: Pushing relaxation if patient becomes more anxious
cautions.description: Insisting on relaxation exercises when they provoke anxiety.

cautions.negative_action: Allowing unfair self-comparisons
cautions.description: Permitting patients to compare themselves to unrealistic ideals.

cautions.negative_action: Ignoring dysfunctional beliefs underlying behavioral issues
cautions.description: Failing to address root cognitive causes.

cautions.negative_action: Failing to frame repeated distraction from distress as counterproductive
cautions.description: Not helping patients see that avoidance perpetuates distress.

cautions.negative_action: Attempting to teach image identification prematurely
cautions.description: Stopping image work when patient struggles initially.
cautions.risk: Missed treatment benefits and skill acquisition.

cautions.negative_action: Being intrusive or forcing recounting of distressing images
cautions.description: Pressuring patient to discuss images when unwilling.

cautions.negative_action: Pathologizing or judging image content
cautions.description: Acting judgmental regarding the nature of patient images.

cautions.negative_action: Focusing only on verbal thoughts, neglecting imagery when distress is high
cautions.description: Ignoring imagery content in favor of verbal cognitions.

cautions.negative_action: Rushing techniques without adequate emotional processing
cautions.description: Moving too quickly through interventions before patient is ready.

cautions.negative_action: Assigning homework too difficult for patient’s current state
cautions.description: Selecting tasks that exceed patient's capabilities.

cautions.negative_action: Pushing patients into assignments they do not understand or agree to
cautions.description: Forcing assignments without buy-in, especially early.

cautions.negative_action: Neglecting to provide rationale for homework or making assignments punitive
cautions.description: Not explaining the value or framing tasks as punishment.

cautions.negative_action: Implying failure when homework is not completed
cautions.description: Making patient feel unsuccessful if homework is missed.

cautions.negative_action: Failing to explore reasons for nonadherence
cautions.description: Not investigating why patients do not complete tasks.

cautions.negative_action: Reinforcing perfectionism with homework
cautions.description: Encouraging flawless execution.

cautions.negative_action: Leaving homework vague or ill-defined
cautions.description: Assigning tasks without clear instructions.

cautions.negative_action: Fostering patient dependence or assuming responsibility for all problems
cautions.description: Taking over problem solving instead of building patient agency.

cautions.negative_action: Minimizing or invalidating fears and emotions around termination
cautions.description: Not addressing emotional responses to therapy ending.
cautions.risk: Distress and poor coping with transition.

cautions.negative_action: Attributing all improvement to external factors
cautions.description: Giving credit to therapist/circumstance/medication only.

cautions.negative_action: Skipping preparation for setbacks and relapse
cautions.description: Not planning for challenges after therapy.

cautions.negative_action: Focusing on non-problems or issues patient does not wish to address
cautions.description: Spending session time on incidental or resolved issues.
cautions.risk: Loss of session utility and patient frustration.

cautions.negative_action: Persisting with ineffective interventions despite affect shifts
cautions.description: Continuing approaches when patient is distressed or activating core beliefs.
cautions.risk: Increased patient distress and reduced benefit.

cautions.negative_action: Pushing patients to solutions they are unprepared for
cautions.description: Encouraging skills or answers prematurely.

cautions.negative_action: Neglecting to adapt CBT methods for specific disorders or patient characteristics
cautions.description: Using standard approaches without customization.

cautions.negative_action: Failing to seek feedback or repair ruptured alliance
cautions.description: Not addressing or fixing relationship issues.

cautions.negative_action: Assuming patient resistance or engaging in blame
cautions.description: Blaming either patient or self for therapeutic difficulties.

cautions.negative_action: Failing to seek or respond to feedback
cautions.description: Ignoring patient reactions and input.
cautions.risk: Missed opportunities for course correction and engagement.

cautions.negative_action: Persuading or challenging cognitions prematurely
cautions.description: Arguing against patient thoughts without guided discovery.

cautions.negative_action: Using didactic, controlling, or unempathetic approaches
cautions.description: Managing therapy without warmth or flexibility.

cautions.negative_action: Allowing own negative thoughts or assumptions to deter intervention
cautions.description: Letting therapist beliefs about sessions prevent problem-solving.

cautions.negative_action: Neglecting patient doubts about cognitive model or process
cautions.description: Not addressing patient uncertainties about therapy.

cautions.negative_action: Overlooking contextual or biological obstacles
cautions.description: Not considering situational or physical contributors to progress difficulties.

cautions.negative_action: Skipping therapist practice with CBT techniques before using with patients
cautions.description: Not personally rehearsing methods before introducing in therapy.

cautions.negative_action: Assigning homework in a vague or overly complex manner
cautions.description: Giving unclear or complicated assignments.

cautions.negative_action: Relying on non-CBT modalities during initial CBT practice
cautions.description: Using previous therapy methods rather than CBT when starting.

cautions.negative_action: Failing to elicit or review feedback regularly
cautions.description: Not seeking patient input about therapy.
cautions.risk: Missed opportunities for engagement and course correction.

cautions.negative_action: Using debate or persuasion instead of guided discovery
cautions.description: Arguing with patient rather than collaboratively exploring cognitions.

cautions.negative_action: Setting inappropriate or non-collaborative agendas
cautions.description: Planning sessions without patient involvement.

cautions.negative_action: Treating overly complex or difficult patients during early CBT skill development
cautions.description: Working with complicated cases before developing adequate CBT skills.

cautions.negative_action: Neglecting informed consent for session recording and supervision
cautions.description: Recording or sharing session data without patient permission.
cautions.risk: Ethical violations and loss of trust.

user_profile.Description: Degree of cognitive flexibility, pattern of information processing, and tendency toward abstract vs. concrete thinking. Includes insight and self-reflection.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = Extremely rigid/concrete thinking; 1 = Highly flexible/abstract, easily engages in metacognition

user_profile.Description: Stability of mood, affective lability, baseline temperament, and emotion regulation capacities.
Characteristic ways of relating to others, social motivation, attachment patterns, and capacity for trust, intimacy or withdrawal.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = Profound social withdrawal/mistrust; 1 = Highly engaged, trusting, and open in relationships

user_profile.Description: Typical stress coping strategies and behavioral patterns: avoidance, ritualistic/compulsive acts, impulsivity, adaptive engagement.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = Maladaptive coping predominates; 1 = Adaptive/problem-focused coping predominates

user_profile.Description: Degree of awareness and acceptance of mental health concerns; typical style of engagement, motivation, honesty, and alliance-building in therapy sessions.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = No insight/actively resistant in session; 1 = Full insight/highly collaborative and motivated

user_profile.Description: Early life experiences, parental/caregiver relationships, and their effect on attachment (secure, insecure, disinhibited, etc.) and baseline vulnerability.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = Profound attachment disruption/neglect; 1 = Secure, nurturing attachments

user_profile.Description: Stable aspects of identity (culture, race, gender, sexual orientation, beliefs), acculturation, and their impact on symptom presentation, stigma, explanatory models, and typical engagement.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = High identity-related stress/discordance; 1 = Identity is affirmed and not a source of stress

user_profile.Description: Presence and impact of other psychiatric or medical conditions that shape stable traits, coping, and therapeutic process.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = Multiple severe comorbidities; 1 = No comorbidities, fully physically healthy

user_profile.Description: Dispositional impulsivity, self-control, behavioral inhibition, and resistance to urges/aggression.
Stability, quality, and availability of social, familial, or community supports, and their influence on engagement and outcomes.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = No/loss of support network; 1 = Highly supportive, stable network

user_profile.Description: Typical level of internal motivation or ambivalence to change and engage in CBT; stage of change (precontemplation → action/maintenance).
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = Not motivated/precontemplative; 1 = Highly motivated and ready for change
